intro: Teucrium bogoutdinovae, commonly known as the Bogoutdinov's germander, is a rare and endemic plant species native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone soils and thrives in alpine environments. Its small, tubular flowers are usually blue to purple in color, and it produces small, four-angled fruits. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.
